reviewText:
Early Access Review

(NOTE, this game requires a 64bit OS)

This is a unique survival/crafting/exploration game with an awesome art style, and simply fun gameplay. There are multiple bioms with many odd creatures in them, with much more on the way it seems. Check their Trello to see what the devs are working on
(https://trello.com/b/yxoJrFgP/subnautica).

Currently, as of 3/21/15, you can do just about everything in the game in an hour or less, if you're fast enough, but dispite that, I've already enjoyed almost 24hrs of this game. I do recommend this game to anyone who like survival/open world exploration games. The art style kinda feels like that of the Windwaker, and I really enjoy the handcrafted enviroments. The world is huge, and yes, handcrafted. You can really feel the love put into every corner of the map, and it's far from done.

Still in early access but what is in game is very polished and enjoyable. Updates are regular, and the devs are involved with the community.

I'll try and update this guide as the game gets farther along.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite the game being far from its official release date, and my fear of early access disappointment, I took the PLUNGE with Subnautica. The prospect of underwater survival was just too mouthwatering to resist, and having been obsessed with submarines from a young age, could not turn down the offer. I'll also do my best to review this without spoiling the game, because it's the mystery that makes it fun.

Subnautica is beautiful in every aspect. The visuals, the variety of biomes, flora and fauna, and the sound effects are spine tingling. The ingredients of the game allow for exploration, hardcore survival and a huge element of creativity. From prepping deep sea dives, to creating lavish sea bases, it's all there.

What's more - it's horrifying. Once you go beyond the familiar start-of-game biome, you'll discover there are more things out there to kill you. You go from apex predator to bottom-of-the-chain prey in split seconds. But you'll only ever find out once you get too close, and by then it's too late. It's a quick learning curve. Bone chilling growl? Teeth? NOPE.

In a way it's like Minecraft, meets Depth, meets Silent Hunter. You have the harvesting of resources like Minecraft, the fear of predators like Depth, and the claustrophobia of Silent Hunter. Maybe throw in a bit of Amnesia: The Dark Descent too.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is quickly taking over my life and I don't regret a thing.

Where do I even start on reviewing this game? It has to be (in my opinion at least) one of the best early access games out there. Even without further content additions there are hours upon hours of game time with beautiful graphics and is well worth the price tag as it stands right now.

The survival element is real in this game since many items don't respawn/don't respawn often forcing you to venture more in a quest to further progress on crafting or building as well as the fun task of searching for blueprints. Plus certain sea life that want to take a bite out of you.

There are different game styles depending on whether you want a relaxing near sandbox game on creative, no worry of drinking or eating on freedom, standard survival on..well, survival and the really challenging hardcore mode where death means death and starting all over again.

There are admittedly a few bugs still lurking in this game but it's easy to tell how the developers take them seriously with the many updates in fixing those found which brings me to another point, the developers are very active and put out content updates and fixes often, another reason I see this as one of the best early access games around right now.

Highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is amazing. Graphics is great, sounds are outstanding, makes you really feel like you're in an alien planet ocean.
Very frequent updates, however you have to start a new game to avoid losing stuff / see all the content. That makes me play a lot less as I don't like to start from scratch every month or two.
Resource gathering is a bit tiresome because it always takes one to six slots of your inventory. Same type resources do not stack into one slot, so you're fairly quickly forced to return to your base. You also need a lot of storage to store everything you have. However, once you get a cyclops submarine and place some storage cases on it it's a lot easier.
One thing i'd really want to see in this game is some threat to your base. Once it is build it can only be damaged / destroyed by you. If there was for example some nighttime life form that could damage it (just a little is enough, make it flood) it would be a lot more interesting.
You're probably going to need a decent pc for this game. I had to replace mine to run smoothly (was quite outdated tho). As it is early access game performance is expected to improve.
I rate the game in the current state 7.5/10. Every update adds a lot of awesome stuff and i'm really excited to see all the content that is to come.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Despite the game being far from its official release date, and my fear of early access disappointment, I took the PLUNGE with Subnautica. The prospect of underwater survival was just too mouthwatering to resist, and having been obsessed with submarines from a young age, could not turn down the offer. I'll also do my best to review this without spoiling the game, because it's the mystery that makes it fun.

Subnautica is beautiful in every aspect. The visuals, the variety of biomes, flora and fauna, and the sound effects are spine tingling. The ingredients of the game allow for exploration, hardcore survival and a huge element of creativity. From prepping deep sea dives, to creating lavish sea bases, it's all there.

What's more - it's horrifying. Once you go beyond the familiar start-of-game biome, you'll discover there are more things out there to kill you. You go from apex predator to bottom-of-the-chain prey in split seconds. But you'll only ever find out once you get too close, and by then it's too late. It's a quick learning curve. Bone chilling growl? Teeth? NOPE.

In a way it's like Minecraft, meets Depth, meets Silent Hunter. You have the harvesting of resources like Minecraft, the fear of predators like Depth, and the claustrophobia of Silent Hunter. Maybe throw in a bit of Amnesia: The Dark Descent too.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is the late twenty-second century and a faceless protagonist has crashed landed on an ocean planet in the middle of a terraforming mission. He is the only survivor and the spacecraft, the Aurora, soon goes nuclear and turns a disproportionately small amount of the planet radioactive.

Not to worry, because his escape pod is filled with just enough space age equipment to eat fish and yes, this guy is you. The goal of the game is to survive long enough to explore the planet.

As a survival sandbox game, it will probably be compared to Minecraft quite a lot. It's a completely unrelated game, let's get that out of the way. There's very little in the way of building, mostly exploring.

It's a very pretty game. The cartoonish art style is reminiscent of No Man's Sky and it has the most fantastic creatures. It can be unforgivingly hard at times, though, to actually maintain a seabase as it can actually leak. You will not be killing very much in the early game, as the most you'll have at that point is a small knife. Late game, you'll have a submarine, torpedoes, a freeze-gun, but you still won't be killing very much. It's mostly about going ooh" and "aah" and the amazing looking game
date: which actually looks kind of awful on lower-end machines. You need a fairly decent computer for it to look really impressive.\n\nThe developers are fairly reliable and it's a game about admiring everything instead of killing everything (though I imagine it would be fun to watch people try to
recommended: as most big fish will kill you) so I definitely recommend it.\n\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Over the course of the last fiur years survival games have been increasing in popularity. We've gotten some awful ones, and we've gotten some pretty good ones. Subnautica is beyond good.
While the game is considered to be early access. You can play the more unstable experimental mode that has every new update soon to be implemented into the full version. You can also play the stable version with all complete game elements.
This game is regularly updated, each update bringing something new to the table.
The crafting system is simple yet effective, seabase building is absolutely fantastic, and with monsters and scenery like these travelling for resources is never a chore.
With regular updates there will be new things to do very often so long as the devs keep working on this fantastic game.
10/10 IGN

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Well I bought this game when it was on special but would now easily of payed full price for this gem. It is a game that is simplistic in doing what needs to be done crafting wise, but also enough of a challenge to make all the gathering of ingredients worth it. It also has adjustable difficulty levels which can add in hunger/thirst, or just have hp to worry about which can come in handy for new people to the game.

The ocean has some of the most beautiful sights to see which begs you to keep searching through to new depths, and rewards you with upgrades obtained by scanning or new types of minerals to use in crafting. The creatures also make all of these environments come alive, but also be pretty terrifying at times too with some areas having giant monsters out to get you! Also for a early access game I have only had 2 major glitches which I was able to fix by quitting and reloading the save.

All in all I 100% reccommend this game to anyone who enjoys open world exploration games or love bioshock!
PS This game takes its toll on your graphics so if your computer isn't up to scratch try lower graphics

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(NOTE, this game requires a 64bit OS)

This is a unique survival/crafting/exploration game with an awesome art style, and simply fun gameplay. There are multiple bioms with many odd creatures in them, with much more on the way it seems. Check their Trello to see what the devs are working on
(https://trello.com/b/yxoJrFgP/subnautica).

Currently, as of 3/21/15, you can do just about everything in the game in an hour or less, if you're fast enough, but dispite that, I've already enjoyed almost 24hrs of this game. I do recommend this game to anyone who like survival/open world exploration games. The art style kinda feels like that of the Windwaker, and I really enjoy the handcrafted enviroments. The world is huge, and yes, handcrafted. You can really feel the love put into every corner of the map, and it's far from done.

Still in early access but what is in game is very polished and enjoyable. Updates are regular, and the devs are involved with the community.

I'll try and update this guide as the game gets farther along.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I picked up this game on sale after some amazing reviews of my favorite let's players on youtube, and I do not regret it. Subnautica is a survival style adventure game with some really unique features and what I'd definitely consider a unique setting. In an oceanic environment, the flora and fauna are stunning and, for an early access, rather varied. The updates have absolutely, drastically changed the feel of the game and the way that it flows in recent weeks.

Some honest points to make:
The crafting system is fluid, but slightly scattered. My game bugged and an entire set of collectibles was absent, and I had to console command to retrieve the item. There are entire areas of unassigned landscape - you can't escape the early access part of it. At this point, there's little to do but explore, build your base, and farm for materials, but the story is shaping up to be an interesting one. I fully intend to keep playing and endorse the full release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The first tag for this game should be horror."  Because fear has dominated my experience with this game and I absolutely love it.

It must be said early on that this game suffers from performance and framerate issues.  It's early access
date: so it's forgiveable and will be fixed someday
recommended: but you MUST understand that buying this game now will definitely get you a product that does not perform as you hope it will. Buyer be advised.\n\nBeyond the performance issues this game is outstanding and only continues to improve itself.  The ocean is as vast and vibrant as you would hope.  It teams with different types of life many of which are not unlike our own underwater horrors.  The terrain is fun and immersive.  It has geological activity.  The day/night cycle is fast
hoursPlayed: bordering on too fast
voteText:
but it certainly keeps you alert as night time is... less comfortable.

Which leads me nicely into my favorite part of this game - the sense of isolation and fear.  Reaching my escape pod sometimes borders on therapeutic it feels so good. In no other survival game that I've played has the feeling of "exploration" been so genuine.  New areas are as fascinating and rewarding as they are foreign and unnerving. My pod drifted out over some very deep water and I experienced one of my first real moments of true fear as I swam out to it.  Looking down into the black...

If you like survival and exploration games or if you as a person have the slightest apprehension of the real open ocean then I strongly recomend this game; as it will challenge your senses and illustrate the boundaries of your comfort zone.  The price is excellent given the amount of content and hyper-realistic atmosphere it creates."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I should preface this by saying that I own no other survival games, and that in general I avoided the early-access H1ZI-Rust event like the plague.

This game is probably one of the best, if not the best, sandbox survival games on Steam. Not only is the game fascinating, but the devs are probably the best around. They are very transparent with their development plans, updating their fans on the current projects on this site[trello.com], as well as getting to know people on the subreddit.

Beyond the fantastic people crafting this game, you have a beautiful game set on an alien water planet. As you swim around the shallows, gathering supplies to begin crafting your new home, you encounter an alien ecosystem, complete with the smallest, cutest fish like the Peeper to the giant, terrifying Reaper Leviathan[vignette4.wikia.nocookie.net], whose howls and screams that echo the murky depths will haunt your nightmares.

You build power structures, habitats, hunt for fish, scan blueprints, while the sun and moon pivot about your head. The blue skies and deep indigo depths invite you, as you pass mammoth docile giants and fast, scaly sharks. This game will make you fear the deep, but make you also want to explore it.

The tl:dr of this is that this game, set in a seemingly untapped locale (ocean), provides some great survival, building fun. The world is beutiful, the mechanics good and improving with every update, and the ocean teeming with a seemingly viable and alive ecosystem. Top that off with an amazing studio and a relatively low price, and I would say this game is a great deal.

Please, do yourself a favor. Pick it up, and experience it.

I rate 8/8 m8.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nPersonally, this game has about the same amount of content as some fully released games right now and is very pretty for an early access game. The storyline is isn't very long and you don't see too much of it in the game and most of the story is in little hints about other bases and lifepods found scattered around the map plus the signals which can lead you to some places to get more hints about what happened to everyone else. The game does only have one map, but if you couldn't find a certain biome there is little chance of someone being able to help you with the randomly generated maps. This won't be a full review because the game is still in early access and most things said bad in reviews would probably be fixed in the full release of the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm going to start by saying I don't think I have ever played a survival game that's excited me this much, let alone an Early Access game.

Subnautica is awesome. I love everything about it. The graphics, the gameplay, the sound, the theme. The first time you stand atop your life pod and look around you at the endless ocean and the hulk of your ship in the distance is astonishing. While the game is certainly not finished, the scale and need to explore the game inspires is what keeps me coming back.

The crafting system is rather simple, with the usual combine these materials to make this" mechanic but it works. And the results are rewarding. When you finally get your first sub
date: it changes the whole way you play and allows you to go much farther and deeper than you could before. The base building is a lot of fun as well. Joining all the different modules together to create something unique is one of the things I love most and I can't wait to see what Unknown Worlds do with this system in the future.\n\nAt the moment
recommended: there is not a huge amount of content and depending on how focused you are you might get through it all in 10 hours or less
hoursPlayed: plus there are only fragments of a story right now but for $20
voteText: I think it's worth it and I personally am very much looking forward to it's continued development."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I picked up this game on sale after some amazing reviews of my favorite let's players on youtube, and I do not regret it. Subnautica is a survival style adventure game with some really unique features and what I'd definitely consider a unique setting. In an oceanic environment, the flora and fauna are stunning and, for an early access, rather varied. The updates have absolutely, drastically changed the feel of the game and the way that it flows in recent weeks.

Some honest points to make:
The crafting system is fluid, but slightly scattered. My game bugged and an entire set of collectibles was absent, and I had to console command to retrieve the item. There are entire areas of unassigned landscape - you can't escape the early access part of it. At this point, there's little to do but explore, build your base, and farm for materials, but the story is shaping up to be an interesting one. I fully intend to keep playing and endorse the full release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The first tag for this game should be horror."  Because fear has dominated my experience with this game and I absolutely love it.

It must be said early on that this game suffers from performance and framerate issues.  It's early access
date: so it's forgiveable and will be fixed someday
recommended: but you MUST understand that buying this game now will definitely get you a product that does not perform as you hope it will. Buyer be advised.\n\nBeyond the performance issues this game is outstanding and only continues to improve itself.  The ocean is as vast and vibrant as you would hope.  It teams with different types of life many of which are not unlike our own underwater horrors.  The terrain is fun and immersive.  It has geological activity.  The day/night cycle is fast
hoursPlayed: bordering on too fast
voteText:
but it certainly keeps you alert as night time is... less comfortable.

Which leads me nicely into my favorite part of this game - the sense of isolation and fear.  Reaching my escape pod sometimes borders on therapeutic it feels so good. In no other survival game that I've played has the feeling of "exploration" been so genuine.  New areas are as fascinating and rewarding as they are foreign and unnerving. My pod drifted out over some very deep water and I experienced one of my first real moments of true fear as I swam out to it.  Looking down into the black...

If you like survival and exploration games or if you as a person have the slightest apprehension of the real open ocean then I strongly recomend this game; as it will challenge your senses and illustrate the boundaries of your comfort zone.  The price is excellent given the amount of content and hyper-realistic atmosphere it creates."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I should preface this by saying that I own no other survival games, and that in general I avoided the early-access H1ZI-Rust event like the plague.

This game is probably one of the best, if not the best, sandbox survival games on Steam. Not only is the game fascinating, but the devs are probably the best around. They are very transparent with their development plans, updating their fans on the current projects on this site[trello.com], as well as getting to know people on the subreddit.

Beyond the fantastic people crafting this game, you have a beautiful game set on an alien water planet. As you swim around the shallows, gathering supplies to begin crafting your new home, you encounter an alien ecosystem, complete with the smallest, cutest fish like the Peeper to the giant, terrifying Reaper Leviathan[vignette4.wikia.nocookie.net], whose howls and screams that echo the murky depths will haunt your nightmares.

You build power structures, habitats, hunt for fish, scan blueprints, while the sun and moon pivot about your head. The blue skies and deep indigo depths invite you, as you pass mammoth docile giants and fast, scaly sharks. This game will make you fear the deep, but make you also want to explore it.

The tl:dr of this is that this game, set in a seemingly untapped locale (ocean), provides some great survival, building fun. The world is beutiful, the mechanics good and improving with every update, and the ocean teeming with a seemingly viable and alive ecosystem. Top that off with an amazing studio and a relatively low price, and I would say this game is a great deal.

Please, do yourself a favor. Pick it up, and experience it.

I rate 8/8 m8.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I would have to say that Subnautica is one of the most well crafted games that I have ever played.  For me, it's an example of a sandbox-style game done right.  As much as procedurally generated worlds are an amazing technical achievement, they lack what Subnautica has - a genuine attention to detail with regards to the world design.

It doesn't stop there though.  The crafting system in the game is really, really well done.  Some folks might find it restrictive if they have come to appreciate building things at block and wall level, but I personally found it nice to build bases with at a slightly less granular level.

Finally, it's been a long while since I've wanted to upgrade my gaming machine to get the best graphics experience possible.  In most cases, you will get slightly nicer shadows, or slightly more menacing looking zombies.  I think in the case of Subnautica the experience would be absolutely amazing with all the graphics maxxed out.

All in all, a great game to add to your library!

For an early access game this is brillaint

If it were full release it would be good with a few issues...and that's pretty good for an early access game.

I've played this for a while now and I've had a lot of fun. I now have a base, my seamoth, the moon bay and I'm now looking for cyclops parts and getting more adventurous in doing so. All the NPC's work well, the AI works fine, bugs are minimal and other than when the game is loading bits like the mushroom forest, it runs really well.

This game isn;t even finished yet and it's already a lot of fun. It was completely worth the money.

My only gripes are the lack of tutorials (though I'm sure this will be added), the fact that the escape pod moves and there seems to be some sort of bug with finding solar panel fragments as I have found 1 fragment throughout the entire time I've played. Other than that, this game is a lot of fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Usually I resist the vile temptations of early access for personal/universal reasons. This however just hits the spot and seems very much lika a complete game, eventhough expect the usual technical issues and placeholder content now and then.

Subnautica is a fine example why things become good things: Individually nice parts combining to form a working system of awesome. Here you not only get a beautiful underwater experience (which alone might be worth your money) but also a  fun survival crafter with meaningful progression without too much grind.

This game even recreates that special terror of the cold dark depths I tend to feel when swimming too far from shore. Chilling!

+Scenery: Sunlit shallows, kelp forests, black chasms full of bioluminescence. Somewhat breathtaking.
+Atmosphere: If this were 3d or VR...
-Content: Possibly ever in need of more building/crafting options and stuff.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Subnautica is one of those games where you can play for hours on end, it is a very good game with lots of potential for the future.
The Gameplay in subnautica is what you would expect in survival games. Gather food and water and build later. However with things like vehicles in this game it makes it even more addictive as you search for that one last part that youre looking for for the next vehicle.
The building in subnautica is both well executed and satisfying. It is easy to get a hang of and will leave you feeling rewarded after you finally finish that bit of your main base off.

However there are quite a lot of bugs, mostly graphical, but i have come accress a few and none of them dampen the gamneplay in any was

Another thing about this game is the steep learning curve witht he lack of tutorial so if youre not willing to pick up this game and learn how it works then dont buy it because 6 hours in and im still learning.

I would really reccommend this to anyone who likes any sort of survival game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm a fan of survival / building games and really liked this one.

The core of the gameplay revolves around first finding basic resources to keep yourself alive.  Then building tools and sea bases of increasing complexity and usefulness.  Finally, finding new blueprints of more advanced technology to build.  Very absorbing - I have over 115 hours clocked in.  The devs are also very active, buildling a lot of new updates into the game all the time.

The visuals are really stunning and the atmosphere is well done too.

One tip - start by playing on survival mode which turns on hunger and thirst.  This will increase the sense of urgency to your game and make it more fun.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of the 6th May 2016 update, fish now respawn.
In theory, it still doesn't answer the long run ressource depletion, but lots of progress have been made, enough to make the game enjoyable again in my opinion.
With farming, solar panels, fish respawn and the ability to fully recycle constructed elements, I don't see depletion as a pressing issue, as a big part of the daily consumption can be streamlined, and the ocean will look more alive again.

Thanks a lot to the devs for listening to the crowd through the heated but necessary ressource respawn debate. Review happily changed to recommended!

###

Initial review (deprecated).


Firstly, let's clarify something:
Get this game and play it, you'll have fun. I want to give the lovely Subnautica a big thumbs up, and I thought I would.... then I realized something after hours in the game:

Ressources don't respawn. None, ever. Fish, plants, minerals.

I almost can't believe it.
This is simply a huge deal breaker. I went from super happy playing the game to hardly willing to launch it anymore.

Infinite consumption of finite ressources is the long term horizon of the game, which means it's a checkmate from the start, no matter how well you manage.

In a nutshell, a growing radius around your base(s) will gradually become a dead zone, and you'll have to make longer and longer trips to places that haven't been plundered yet.

It means you can never reach equilibrium, a goal that's a huge motivator for me, unless you plan to stay in your base eating your crops all day, and that death and emptiness will prevail no matter what.
It is also inconsistent with the idea of being immersed in an ecosystem, which is the driving point of the game.

Yes, there is a welcomed farming update, a step in the right direction but it does not adress the long term inevitable doom of finite ressources and growingly depressing dead oceans. Where is the pleasure of exploring a thriving one, like on our enchanting first dive?
And how does it make sense that fishes in a tank can reproduce, but not in the wild?
Even if the player didn't exist, the oceans would soon be void of fishes just by the sheer actions of the predators constantly eating and chasing!

This dev choice is not even consistent with the will to design living, coherent ecosystems (while still maintaining the fun). This is NOT how things happen in nature! Incentive to explore should not rely on irreversible and total depletion: that's never why I went exploring in the first place. In the very long term, exploration cannot mathematically even be accomplished, because the point will be reached when doing so consumes more ressources than it yields.

It's pretty sad that such a great game is dragged down by this, although some might not object.

To get a more complete tour of the issue and make up your mind, please check:
http://steamcommunity.com/app/264710/discussions/0/527273789693374590/#p1

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I'm going to start by saying I don't think I have ever played a survival game that's excited me this much, let alone an Early Access game.

Subnautica is awesome. I love everything about it. The graphics, the gameplay, the sound, the theme. The first time you stand atop your life pod and look around you at the endless ocean and the hulk of your ship in the distance is astonishing. While the game is certainly not finished, the scale and need to explore the game inspires is what keeps me coming back.

The crafting system is rather simple, with the usual combine these materials to make this" mechanic but it works. And the results are rewarding. When you finally get your first sub
date: it changes the whole way you play and allows you to go much farther and deeper than you could before. The base building is a lot of fun as well. Joining all the different modules together to create something unique is one of the things I love most and I can't wait to see what Unknown Worlds do with this system in the future.\n\nAt the moment
recommended: there is not a huge amount of content and depending on how focused you are you might get through it all in 10 hours or less
hoursPlayed: plus there are only fragments of a story right now but for $20
voteText: I think it's worth it and I personally am very much looking forward to it's continued development."

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

This game is amazing, I at first though it was going to be another early alpha crappy survival game with Dodgy VR gimmicks (I haven't tried the VR yet but the gameplay without it is very immersive). But it has so much, I was suprised of how much depth there is for a early build game like this, I kept seeing new areas and new creatues. There are still, quite, a few bugs but the developers are very keen to make your experience better with a built in feedback system to talk about any topic and how you feel about the game.

This game is a great survival game but could use some refinement, for exapmle: the plant resources grow back but I have always been able to find more. The Tutorial is pretty bad and I didn't understand the fragement mechanic to unlock new tech but after about my second game I had figured it all out and found it amazing. Awesome visuals, unoptimized to rather frequent framerate drops but amazing design with enviroments and creatures.

8.5/10 (Alpha Build)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Give this game a try. Just do it, do it now.

This is a really solid open-world, survival game, and it's still only in early access. It's hard to know where to begin, there are so many ways in which this game already nails it while still having build up and potential as the devs work on it.

This isn't an action game where you go in to kick butt and destroy everything. This isn't a building/devolopment game where you get to a place of complexity that gameplay collapses in on itself and has no longevity after the initial challenges are met. This isn't a puzzle game where there's a right and wrong answer to what you're supposed to do with a defined order of gameplay. This isn't a game with training wheels on it that's forgiving of all your mistakes while merely tricking you into thinking it's open world."

This is a game that comes in and takes its place with as much simplicity or complexity as you want. You can call the shots and do things in the order you want
date: accomplish various aspects of survival organically without (currently at least) a plot driving you into a set storyline for game development. It submerses you in a world that is familiar yet altogether alien with new surprises coming frequently with updates. It allows you to build and develop your own experience without feeling cramped by a short-sided goal system that micromanages your every move. You can gather just enough resources that you're not in a constant state of emergency
recommended: and yet you are driven to keep exploring
hoursPlayed: keep gathering
voteText: keep doing more and working your way into the world of water you're stranded on.\n\nIf you have any appreciation for exploration

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Time to give this game a proper review. I think it's important to note that I am playing Survival mode, where eating and drinking are required, you have a limited health and oxygen meter, resources are limited and you have to figure out ways to keep your base powered.

Subnautica is a game I found out about through the Vinesauce stream. Even through the stream, I could tell that this game's mechanics were pretty deep. Upon actually playing it, I became hooked. Trying to figure out how to expand my base further as my storage and survival needs grow is incredibly engaging, and the sea is both vast and deep. In addition, it's pretty immersive; I feel actual amazement seeing what the ocean has to offer, and when I found land I was pretty legitimately excited. I'm also pretty excited to see what the future holds for the game, and will most likely be sticking around for version 1.0 and beyond. Fauna and flora variety is also pretty great, ranging from the simple, harmless Peeper to the explosive Crash fish to the deadly Reaper Leviathan, and the various biomes all feel varied and unique; even if some biomes, such as creepvine forests repeat, even those feel unique.

However, if there's one thing I had to complain about, it's the lack of fauna respawning outside of the Crash fish; I'm pretty sure that I've depopulated the entire fish population near my base, giving things like observation decks and glass windows little purpose outside of letting me look at the seas. There's also a variety of bugs and missing features, but that's to be expected as this is in development.

Overall, would I give it my recommendation? Yes. This game has become my favorite survival game and favorite early access game (since Kerbal Space Program left it last year), and I am really excited to see what the future holds for it.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game is one of a kind. It's everything you wish minecraft/the long dark/everything else was but isn't. Not to say those games are bad I've spent an embarrising amount of time on both, but this game takes the freaking cake. It's terrifying, time sucking, beautiful, and satisfying. The artwork is amazing and the all around quality of the game and its put togetherness makes you trust the developers with their own game, which is not something I can say with many games. There's always that fear that all the people crying out for multiplayer will be listened too but I trust that they'll make the right decision because this game is too perfect. And even if they did, the fact that I can spend 30 hours on a game that's in early access says volumes in and of itself.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Easily one of the most engrossing games I've ever played. Despite how simple it is and the lack of 'things to do', the evironment itself will constantly be throwing new hurdles at you without the need for any quest arrow nonsense. There are intense moments of panic as the wildlife takes you by surprise, or you may even become your own worst enemy when you have a panic-attack freak out in an underwater cave and let claustrophobia get the better of you.

In fact, without ever intending on it, I think this is the best horror game I've seen in recent years.

Very easily a 10/10, with content still inbound and coming in at a steady enough pace. I almost wouldn't even believe it were early access. Very minor nitpicking bugbears with some audio effect issues and glitches, but nothing that is too detracting from the awesomeness.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Honestly,

I've only sunk 16 hours into this game, but I really have to crown it to be one of the best Survival games out there. Here are 10 good points I have to say about the game:

1) No zombies.
2) (very) active developers, with a development timeline on Trello, you can track their ideas and development progress.
3) Actual challenging gameplay (at the start), which gets a little easier as you start building a base.
4) Massive scary fauna, some of which will actually get your heart racing when you hear them coming for you.
5) Interesting Biomes, some with fauna that looks really cute to look at, some with fauna that will mess you up if you so much as sneeze in their general direction.
6) Unique base building, incuding different modules, defences, storage modules etc.
7) Some semblence of story line (which is being expanded per update), take the crash sequence update for example.
8) A pretty diverse range of fauna, from small cutesy fish to massive reaper-leviathans that will totally put a crimp on your day.
9) Fish tanks (who doesn't want their own virtual fish).
10) You can totally stab an alien shark to death, it's basically like being in the back alleys of Manchester.

A few bad (or critical points off of the top of my head):

1) No multiplayer / Coop, while this isn't a bad point, it may frustrate some players, not being able to shank alien sharks down with their chums.
2) No way to kill a Reaper Leviathan, so once one has you in its sights, you better pray to sweet lord gaben that he misses you and you can get to that giant sea-shell you're so desperately clammering for.
3) It feels very slow paced, again this is quite cathartic for some, it may not be for everyone.
4) No real objective, the game feels lacking without a major end-game goal, apart from building a base.
5) Saves are not compatable between updates.
6) No mud crabs, I want the ability to have a mudcrab pet and call him citizen snips"
date: please add this asap.\n\nAll in all
hoursPlayed: disregarding all of my semi-negative points (I'm english
voteText: I have to moan about something) I find  it to be a good game to come back to every time that they update it. You have my seal of approval."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

########
UPDATED - Only supports Oculus Rift in VR, there are workarounds but... really?
########

A big open atmospheric underwater world with several diffrent biomes, inhabited with various strange creatures, small, and big. Explore, craft, build and avoiding death sounds like every sandbox survival game, but this is diffrent.

The first 10+ hours in this game was wonderous, having not seen any spoilers or streams, many encounters, sounds, discoveries are very enjoyable ...and scary.

This game is awesome and development is active, refreshing compared to many other halted sandbox survival games. I run this game with experimental beta setting in steam, small patches/hotfixes every day.

CONS:
* Stuttering at times
* Textures and landscapes (mushrooms) sometimes only pop up when you are quite close.
* Some biomes really drops the FPS to it's knees, even with low settings.
* No multiplayer
* Only supports Oculus Rift VR, there are workarounds but ...really?

I would not expect a flawless experience with early access and the development is clearly active so i am sure these issues will be adressed and fixed eventually.

I run this game on an Intel i7 6700K @ 4635MHz 16Gb DDR4 2200MHz and ASUS Geforce GTX980Ti STRIX, but i had the same issues with my older system that ran on and AMD CPU and a single card solution so clearly these issues are not the hardware related.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is THE model for early access development. Game allows painless ingame feedback, devs keep Trello up to date, experimental build is updated daily, big updates are monthly. This is what early access is all about. The content changes and feedback process is enough to make you want to replay the game every update. By buying in early access you are getting you money's worth time and again.

As to the game, it is beautiful, graphically exceptional. The execution is brilliant and the world feels alive. There is a lot of content already and more to come. The game is not violent, and while I love my hack and slash, its nice to have a game focused on something other than killing. There is danger enough to get your heart racing.

My only negative feedback so far, its really easy. I'm waiting for the dev's to add creature attacks on the base and such. Also take the negative with a grain of salt, most things get easy on the tenth replay...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even though it's early and there's not a ton to do, I enjoy what I'm seeing so far.  This isn't so much of a game as it is a 'chillaxin' simulator. Yes, you can play survival mode, but so far I've been cruising around with survival mode off just checking out the beauty of this ocean world.  It's particularly beautiful - and somewhat spooky - at night. It reminds me of Scooby Doo's The Ghostly Creep from the Deep". I also like to hum the Little Mermaid's "Under the Sea" as I swim around.

If you're looking for a underwater sim to relax in this is the way to go. For 20 clams I don't think you'll go wrong.

Edit: As the updates roll out this keeps getting better and better with more stuff to do. Giant subs
recommended: etc. I like where this is goin'!"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI played this game for an hour and then refunded. I then went on to watch some videos of other people playing and saw all the content I was missing and how much work the devs were putting into the future of this game and immediately re-purchased the game. This game is deceptive at first, it's pretty but seems to be sameish after an hour of fooling around until you realize how to unlock the more advanced gear and start exploring further and deeper and properly building up a beautiful base you actually want to live in. This game gets top marks for creativity, visuals, sounds, and replayability. There is quite a bit of placeholder art at the moment which was a disappointment to me but the art that is in place is beautiful. I look forward to playing more of this game (currently played around 6 hours across 2 saves) and discovering what the devs have hidden away in the depths. If you like movies like The Martian and Interstellar I cannot recommend this game enough because it will let you play out your stranded fantasies on an ocean-only alien planet.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is an example for everything that can be done great in terms of the execution of a fresh idea. And exploring a alien planet in the first perspective is something that only video games, or interactive entertainment, can deliver so directly. It's a game I have been wating to be made for many, many years. And these fine ladies and gentlemen delivered like a Sir.

This game is fresh, fascinating, well designed (especially for Early Access), the presentation and sound design is solid, it has a lot of content for e.a., is already relatively polished and it is refreshingly non violent. - Although it does have some combat that is just enough to fit into this world of atmospheric exploration and amazing discovery.

It is also a game children can enjoy and their parents. Aswell as scientifically interested teens. And considering how many more or less badly executed products are out there for this target audience of family entertainment and education, this makes this game stand apart. Because you may not learn that much about biology, but you might find yourself ingrained with a love for life, nature, the sea and the exotic habitats our own planet can offer. Because after all well done science fiction also makes you see your own planet in a new light.

When I played Subnautica for the first time, the sense of wonder and the atmosphere could almost be compared to my first time descending on an alien planet with Samus Aran on the SNES. Also there is also a relatively good amount to do already and, which I really like, you can turn off food, drink and energy demand, fully concentrating on the crafting and exploration part. A feedback function is directly built in, the developers are working quickly and thoroughly.

After all is said and done, I'd really like to see a game like this as a representation for the diversity of interactive entertainment and not a view reduced to Mortal Kombat 23.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Even though it's early and there's not a ton to do, I enjoy what I'm seeing so far.  This isn't so much of a game as it is a 'chillaxin' simulator. Yes, you can play survival mode, but so far I've been cruising around with survival mode off just checking out the beauty of this ocean world.  It's particularly beautiful - and somewhat spooky - at night. It reminds me of Scooby Doo's The Ghostly Creep from the Deep". I also like to hum the Little Mermaid's "Under the Sea" as I swim around.

If you're looking for a underwater sim to relax in this is the way to go. For 20 clams I don't think you'll go wrong.

Edit: As the updates roll out this keeps getting better and better with more stuff to do. Giant subs
recommended: etc. I like where this is goin'!"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has a beautiful underwater world, with very unique creatures inhabiting the depths. There are so many interesting areas to explore, and you can tell the devs put a lot of work into the details. You are on an alien planet covered in water. You crash-landed here, with no idea what type of world it is. You must learn about its inhabitants, and occaisionally eat them, even if they are cute. An awesome survival aspect, that doesn't include the over-used zombie infestation. Instead, you have marine animals, that are both aggressive and friendly.

The game can be peaceful, or scary, depending on what you are doing. There are lots of useful items to craft, resources to gather, and a few cool vehicles to make exploring even easier. One of them includes the giant Cyclops submarine. You can practically live in it.

The devlopers are very open with what they are working on, and there are large updates often. There is an in-game feedback and bug report menu which allows you to submit complaints or feedback in real-time. The game is really unique and fun, and I'm looking forward to every update!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game! Even though everything eats me :( and my base floods :( and my submarines constantly get destroyed by incredibly scary and noisy leviathan things :(

In all seriousness, until the subnautica team decides to add an autosave feature this game is about 6.5/10 overall. Loosing hours of swimming around collecting quartz is made incredibly tedious and very annoying after about 3 crashes. This is early access and you should be careful while buying it, as it is extremely buggy, yet it is also very fun to play.

A couple of the main issues with this game are as follows
* Crashing
* Gets boring collecting materials after a while (main focus of the game is collection of materials, or so it seems.)
*No auto-save feature
*Frame rate, I have 2 gaming computers, one is a laptop, one is a custom built desktop. The desktop can run this game at an average of 35 fps (while dropping below this mark frequently) with a GTX 970 gpu as well as an intel i7-5820k 6 core cpu . If you have anything less poweful than the gpu / cpuI listed, you'd be wasting your money buying this game, as it would be unplayable or nearly so.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've bought this game after seeing a couple people play it on the youtubes, decided to buy it on a sale, and by the Great Beard of Grouchy Odin, I've enjoyed every hour of playing this game (even when the stalker killed me through 15cm of steel), I can and will recommend this to anyone, but don't expect this to glitch free, (early access), the amount of swimming you can do, and the satisfaction you get after crafting so many things to make your life easier! DAMN. This game is stunning, I've played it for a decent amount of time (All hours on hardcore, which I would recommend to anyone since it makes you really not want to die.), but all in all it lacks content. Sure it is early access so we can expect more  to be added, but it seriously needs more creatures (There aren't that many. Don't let the sounds fool you.) The biomes seem to repeat themselves a lot too. In my opinion the content needs to be tripled for it to become a fully fledged game.

Small pros and cons list for the sake of it:

Pros:
- Beautiful game (with VR support)
- Very atmospheric
- Lots to explore
- Surprisngly satisfying crafting system (imo)
- Terra former gun (for making rock gentials. Get it!)
- Supposedly will get better
- Resources don't respawn! (YOU HAVE TO EXPLORE!!!)

Cons (Mostly related to early access):
- Needs more content (creatures, biomes, crafting)
- Crafting needs better explanation (In regards to the Pro: Yes its fun, but lacks proper explanation)
- Buggy as hell
- Unstable
- Its early access.

Its a mastapiece. A buggy one, but a masta piece.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome game. I will break it down into pros and cons. This is my first review, so don't expect much.

PROS:
-Good Graphics
-Smooth Gameplay
-Realistic Survival Modes
-Huge Selection of Flora/Fauna
-HUGE Map
-Addicting
-Creative Mode
-Lots of Crafting

CONS:
-Average Quality Story
-Resources are so hard to find
-Annoying short power supplies
-Food and Water are hard to get
-Fullscreen doesn't work
-Annoying exploding fish
-You can't even get close to the ship without dying
-Everything scares the crap out of you

reviewText:
Early Access Review

LET ME WARN YOU BY SAYING THIS GAME IS STILL IN VERY EARLY ACCESS!

With that said, this game has an abundance of game mechanics already.  There are many things to craft and many resources to collect.  This game already has vehicles, base building and crafting.

PROS -
*Good and easy to learn crafting system
*Tons of exploration and adventure to be had, at some moments your jaw will hit the floor
*The theme and style of this game is awesome
*Diverse crafting system and base building system
*Natural incentives to keep going, like building submarines and upgrading your base

CONS -
*Random crashes
*MAJOR FPS drops when first loading a big saved world
*Low resolution icons and UI
*Some resources can be very hard to find


Conclusion -
I would whole heartedly recommend this game, it has tons of cool places to explore and the atmosphere is incredible.  While there are some stability issues, hopefully that will change as the game keeps going in its development life cycle.  This game is relaxing, awe-inspiring and can be tense sometimes.

8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

SHORT REVIEW:  Full of Potentle, Very atmospheric and very interactive devs

LONG REVIEW : First of all let me say this Subnautica is not even early access. Subnautica is in its design phase, meaning the game is just barley put together, and still it menages to beat many other survival games with its atmosphere alone. However as stated above the game is only just being created, so there are going to be a plethora of bugs and oddity's. Yet, it was well worth the money because, it's a survival, exploration and experimentation game. Don't want to savagely nab fish and eat them? Load up the world in freedom and throw some console commands in and you have perfect atmospheric game to explore the ocean in. To add to this the game even has oculus rift support. In additions to all that the devs are EXTREMELY helpful from responding individually to many problems and they are very interested in listing to players input and suggestion. Even uploading photos of the new work in progress HUD to see if players like it. SUPPORT THIS JEWEL OF A GAME!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSubnautica is a very unique game. It is a game that will inspire so many different games and it is a perfect mix of fantasy and survival. In order to survive you must build bases, submarines, other tools. There is so much potential to this game and I completely look forward to what they will add. I've played 3 hours of the game before writing this and I already have encountered very few bugs, if any. I have not tried the base building yet but I am completely in love with the Cyclops and the seamoth. Currently the only two vehicles in the game but both extremely useful in their own ways. The cyclops is the largest vehicle, able to suck in the seamoth as to bring it along with it do discover and explore new areas and creatures. Personally I believe that the game should be a little more complicated in the sense of different resources and requirements for building. I like a tough game but some people do not. All around I believe this game has amazing potential, I look forward to future updates and upgrades, and also I would absolutely LOVE to see a multiplayer feature! Just saying!
